content:
I look at this page and I understand the procedure for beta backports
https://forge.rust-lang.org/release/beta-backporting.html
I think by now I have figured that stable backports works 99% the same as beta ones, but I don't remember if this is actually documented somewhere in clear letters.
I was thinking if it makes sense to change that page from "Beta backporting" to "Beta and Stable backporting" and add the missing bits (underlining the differences, if any)
the main difference is that stable backports require a point release
I don't know what the process is for deciding whether a backport deserves a point release or not
(me neither, I think stable backports by default warrant a point release) @simulacrum :point_up: ?
stable backports work equivalently to beta from T-compiler perspective, release periodically evaluates whether the approved set warrants a point release
ok. And the reasoning is: we want a point release because this or these backport(s) are so important we cannot wait the usual 6 weeks release cycle, correct?
as I said, from T-compiler perspective, there is no difference; only more scrutiny for a stable backport as it will receive ~no testing before landing on stable

simulacrum said:

reasoning for what?

to decide to have a point release or not. I was imagining a situation in which a stable backport is so important the team decides to release a (f.e.) 1.50.1?
sure, there's not really a checklist or anything, but the release team looks at the patch and how critical the problem is, etc. to evaluate that decision
